title: Weighted Automata and Logics Meet Computational Complexity
abstract:
Abstract
Complexity classes such as #​𝐏#𝐏\#\mathbf{P}, ⊕𝐏direct-sum𝐏\oplus\mathbf{P}, 𝐆𝐚𝐩𝐏𝐆𝐚𝐩𝐏\mathbf{GapP}, 𝐎𝐩𝐭𝐏𝐎𝐩𝐭𝐏\mathbf{OptP}, 𝐍𝐏𝐌𝐕𝐍𝐏𝐌𝐕\mathbf{NPMV}, or the class of fuzzy languages realised
by polynomial-time fuzzy nondeterministic Turing machines, can all be described in terms of a class 𝐍𝐏​[S]𝐍𝐏delimited-[]𝑆\mathbf{NP}[S] for a suitable semiring S𝑆S, defined via weighted Turing machines over S𝑆S
similarly as 𝐍𝐏𝐍𝐏\mathbf{NP} is defined via the classical nondeterministic Turing machines. Other complexity classes of decision problems can be lifted to the quantitative world
using the same recipe as well, and the resulting classes relate to the original ones in the same way as weighted automata or logics relate to their unweighted counterparts.
The article surveys these too-little-known connexions between weighted automata theory and computational complexity theory implicit in the existing literature,
suggests a systematic approach to the study of weighted complexity classes, and presents several new observations strengthening the relation between both fields.
In particular, it is proved that a natural extension of the Boolean satisfiability problem to weighted propositional logic is complete for the class 𝐍𝐏​[S]𝐍𝐏delimited-[]𝑆\mathbf{NP}[S]
when S𝑆S is a finitely generated semiring. Moreover, a class of semiring-valued functions 𝐅𝐏​[S]𝐅𝐏delimited-[]𝑆\mathbf{FP}[S] is introduced for each semiring S𝑆S as a counterpart to the class 𝐏𝐏\mathbf{P},
and the relations between 𝐅𝐏​[S]𝐅𝐏delimited-[]𝑆\mathbf{FP}[S] and 𝐍𝐏​[S]𝐍𝐏delimited-[]𝑆\mathbf{NP}[S] are considered.
